'''Masjid Jami' Al-Makmur Cikini''' is located on Jalan Raden Saleh Raya in [[Cikini, Menteng|Cikini]], [[Central Jakarta]], and is one of the oldest mosques in the locality. It was formerly known as Tjikini Mosque (Indonesian: 'Masjid Tjikini').<ref>{{cite book|last1=Heuken, S.J.|first1=Adolf|title=Mesjid-mesjid tua di Jakarta|date=2003|publisher=Yayasan Cipta Loka Caraka|location=Jakarta|isbn=9799722926|pages=93–95}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Direktorat Jenderal Kebudayaan Republik Indonesia|title=Masjil Al-Makmur (Masjid Cikini) – Jakarta Pusat|url=http://kebudayaanindonesia.net/kebudayaan/1390/masjil-al-makmur-masjid-cikini-jakarta-pusat|website=Kebudayaan Indonesia|accessdate=May 11, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dinas Komunikasi, Informatika dan Kehumasan Pemprov DKI Jakarta|title=Al Makmur Raden Saleh, Masjid|url=http://www.jakarta.go.id/web/encyclopedia/detail/767/Al-Makmur-Raden-Saleh-Masjid|website=Portal Resmi Pemerintah Provinsi DKI Jakarta|publisher=Pemerintah Provinsi DKI Jakarta|accessdate=May 11, 2015}}</ref>
==Early history== The mosque stands on what was the estate of [[Raden Saleh]], the famous late nineteenth-century [[Romantic movement|Romantic]] painter. Oral tradition has it that Raden Saleh himself allowed local Muslims to build a prayer house on his estate, sometime in 1850. In 1897, the late artist's wife sold the estate to the Alatas family, a prominent [[Arab Indonesians|Peranakan Arab]] clan of colonial landlords and [[Captain of The Arabs|officials]].
==Legal Limbo== Some thirty years later, [[Sayyid]] Ismail bin Sayyid Abdoellah bin Alwi Alatas sold part of the estate to [[Queen Emma of the Netherlands|Koningin Emma Stichting]], a foundation that would later build and manage Cikini Hospital (Indonesian: 'Rumah Sakit Cikini'). The old mosque was excluded from the transaction due to an ongoing ownership dispute between the Sayyid and the mosque. Around this time, the simple old structure was moved to the banks of the [[Ciliwung]] to enable worshippers to undertake [[wudu]] in the river.
After Sayyid Ismail's victory in the courts, the land on which the mosque stood was sold to Koningin Emma Stichting in 1923. A year later, the hospital board officially requested the mosque board to move the house of worship further away from its present site.
==Staying power== The mosque authorities, however, refused since they consider the land a legacy, or [[waqf]], left to the community by Raden Saleh.
To ensure the mosque's survival ''in situ'', a committee was formed to transform the old simple prayer house into a permanent, concrete structure. Among the committee members were [[Agus Salim]], [[Mas Mansur]] and [[Cokroaminoto]]. Between 1932 and 1934, the mosque underwent further renovation and expansion work, financed by [[Sarekat Islam]]. These efforts helped stave off efforts to have the mosque moved away, though the building remained in a legal limbo for many decades to come. It was only in 1991 that Cikini Hospital bequeathed - for good - to the mosque the land which it has occupied since 1850.

In the 19th century conversions from Judaism and Zoroastrianism are well documented - indeed such a change of status removing legal and social protections.<ref>{{cite book| last =Maneck (née Stiles) | pages =256 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=9ykelPf5GY0C | isbn = 9781845118914}}</ref>
Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,<ref name="iranhistory">{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan |authorlink= Moojan Momen | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | date = | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-16}}</ref> promulgating the promotion of [[female education]] as a priority concern,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }}</ref> and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics.<ref name="iranhistory"/> Prior to 1911 a private school for girls existed in Tehran which was opened by Iranian Bahá'í women.<ref name="RK">{{cite journal| last = Rostam-Kolayi | first =Jasamin | title =Origins of Iran's Modern Girls' Schools: From Private/National to Public/State| journal =[[Journal of Middle East Women's Studies]] | volume =4 | issue =3 | pages =55–88 |publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | jstor =10.2979/MEW.2008.4.3.58 | doi =10.2979/MEW.2008.4.3.58 | date =Fall 2008 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.2979/MEW.2008.4.3.58 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> During the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] situations required the close of the school.
Although ‘Abdu'l-Bahá had instructed the Bahá'ís in Iran not to take part in open defiance of the government (and they did not participate in the street demonstrations and the taking of sanctuary in the British Legation in Tehran in the summer of 1906) during the period of the Persian Constitutional Revolution they did broadly support the Constitutionalist cause.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Momen | first = Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen| title =The Baha'is and the Constitutional Revolution: The Case of Sari, Mazandaran, 1906–1913 | journal =Iranian Studies | volume =41 |issue =3 | pages =343–363 | publisher =Taylor & Francis group | date = 20 May 2008 | url =http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00210860801981310 | doi =10.1080/00210860801981310 | accessdate = 2012-03-29}}</ref>
[[Image:Tarbiyat School, Tehran, ca 1911.jpg|thumb|250px|from the official website of the [[Bahá'í International Community]], [http://denial.bahai.org/003.php ''The History of Bahá'í Educational Efforts in Iran'']. ]] Tarbiyat-i Banat (Girls’ Education), established in 1911 in Tehran, was the most respected Baha’i girls’ school. Founded on the efforts of private school for girls by Bahá'ís,<ref name="RK"/> it was re-opened under the direction of an Iranian Bahá'í boys’ school committee and several American Bahá'í women [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] who moved in order to support the goals of the religion. Even though it catered to the Iranian Bahá'í community, Tarbiyat attracted children from non-Bahá'í families, as the curriculum was largely secular.
The situation of the Bahá'ís improved under the [[Pahlavi dynasty]] when the government actively sought to secularize public life however there were still organizations actively persecuting the Bahá'ís in addition to there being curses children would learn decrying the Báb, a central figure of the religion, and Bahá'ís.<ref name="debate">{{cite book | last = Fischer | first = Michael|authorlink = Michael M. J. Fischer | last2 = Abedi | first2 = Mehdi | title = Debating Muslims | publisher = University of Wisconsin Press | year = 1990 | location = Madison, Wisconsin | pages = 48–54, 222–250 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=J5RGlpx0j8sC&pg=PA48 | isbn = 0299124347}}</ref> See [[Hojjatieh]]. The founder of [[SAVAK]], [[Teymur Bakhtiar]], took a pick-ax to a Bahá'í building himself at the time.<ref name="Sept13">{{Cite news | last = Samii | first = Bill | title = Iran Report: September 13, 2004|newspaper = Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty | publisher = Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Inc. | date = 13 September 2004 | url = http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1342699.html| accessdate = 2009-12-11}}</ref> See [[Persecution of Bahá'ís#Early 20th century and the Pahlavi Dynasty|Persecution during the early 20th century and during the Pahlavi Dynasty]].
The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.<ref>{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen|authorlink= Moojan Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}}</ref> Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. World-wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. However the modern history of [[persecution of Bahá'ís]] in Iran is extensive and prevented these kinds of developments in Iran: *[[Persecution of Bahá'ís#Islamic Revolution and Republic|During the Iranian revolution and Islamic Republic]] *[[Persecution of Bahá'ís#Current situation|Current situation]] *[[Cultural genocide#The case of the Bahá'ís of Iran|Cultural genocide of the Bahá'ís of Iran]]
Despite the persecution, one of many [[Bahá'í school]]s in the world, the [[Bahá'í Institute for Higher Education]], "an elaborate act of communal self-preservation",<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/world/iran-closes-university-run-covertly-by-the-bahais.html?scp=1&sq=%22an%20elaborate%20act%20of%20communal%20self-preservation%22&st=cse | publisher = New York Times | title = Iran Closes 'University' Run Covertly By the Bahais| date=1998-10-29| first = Ethan | last = Bronner | accessdate = 2011-12-09}}</ref> was set up, though it has been systematically raided. Between 1987 and 2005 the Iranian authorities closed down the university several times<ref name="affolter_bihe">{{cite journal | first = Friedrich W. | last = Affolter | title = Resisting Educational Exclusion: The Bahai Institute of Higher Education in Iran |journal= International Journal of Diaspora, Indigenous and Minority Education | issue = 1 |volume = 1 | pages = 65–77 | year = 2007| url =http://eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/search/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ814786&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ814786 | issn = 1559-5692}}</ref> as part of the pattern of suppressing the Bahá'í community.<ref>{{cite book | last = Leith| first = John Barnabas | editor-last = Ghanea-Hercock|editor-first = Nazila | editor2-last =Stephens | editor2-first = Alan | editor3-last =Walden | editor3-first = Raphael |title = Does God believe in human rights?: essays on religion and human rights | publisher =Martinus Nijhoff Publishers| year =2007| page = 134 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=Q0KGYMTtsK4C&pg=PA134#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn = 9789004152540}}</ref> Between September 30 and October 3, 1998,<ref>{{cite book | title = Directory of persecuted scientists, health professionals, and engineers |publisher = American Association for the Advancement of Science, Science and Human Rights Program | year = 1999 | page = 79 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=B9juAAAAMAAJ&dq=BIHE+Baha%27i&q=BIHE#search_anchor | isbn = 9780871686336}}</ref><ref name="ihrdc_p54">{{cite web|publisher=Iran Human Rights Documentation Center |title=A Faith Denied: The Persecution of the Baha'is of Iran |year=2007|accessdate=2011-12-09|format=PDF | page = 39 | url =http://www.iranhrdc.org/english/publications/reports/3149-a-faith-denied-the-persecution-of-the-baha-is-of-iran.html?p=39}}</ref> and most recently again on 22 May 2011, officials from the Ministry of Intelligence entered the homes of academic staff of the [[Bahá'í Institute for Higher Education]], a university in Iran designed and managed by the Bahá'í community for Iranian Bahá'ís as a Bahá'í school for those who are excluded from access to higher education in their country, seizing books, computers and personal effects and shutting down buildings used for the school.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.iranpresswatch.org/post/7837|publisher = Iran Press Watch | title = Many searches and 14 arrests of BIHE faculty | accessdate = 2011-12-09 | date = 2011-05-23}}</ref>
After a wave of arrests, [[Shirin Ebadi]] volunteered to be the lawyer for the arrested Bahá'í leadership of Iran in June 2008.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Local Baha'is worry about their fellow believers in Iran |publisher=The Chatham News |date=24 February 2009 |url=http://www.chathamdailynews.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=1447519 |accessdate=2 March 2009 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> By December 29 the Islamic authorities closed Ebadi's Center for Defenders of Human Rights, raiding her private office and seizing her computers and files.<ref name="MOAVENI">{{cite web|last=Moaveni |first=Azadeh |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123120656371156129 |title=Iran's Nobel Laureate Has Become a Target of the Regime. Azadeh MOAVENI. JANUARY 6, 2009 |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=6 January 2009 |accessdate=9 June 2011}}</ref>
Indeed, several agencies and experts and journals have published concerns about viewing the developments as a case of [[genocide]]: [[Roméo Dallaire]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Dallaire |first=Roméo |authorlink=Roméo Dallaire |title=Baha'i People in Iran—Inquiry |work=Statements from Roméo Dallaire |publisher=The Liberal caucus in the Senate |date=29 November 2011 |url=http://www.liberalsenateforum.ca/In-The-Senate/Statement/14788_Bahai-People-in-IranInquiry |accessdate=2012-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106032336/http://www.liberalsenateforum.ca/In-The-Senate/Statement/14788_Bahai-People-in-IranInquiry |archivedate=2014-01-06 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dallaire |first=Roméo |authorlink=Roméo Dallaire |title=Baha'i Community in Iran |work=Statements from Roméo Dallaire |publisher=The Liberal caucus in the Senate |date=16 June 2010 |url=http://www.liberalsenateforum.ca/In-The-Senate/Statement/10009_Bahai-Community-in-Iran |accessdate=2012-03-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221081148/http://www.liberalsenateforum.ca/In-The-Senate/Statement/10009_Bahai-Community-in-Iran |archivedate=2011-02-21 |df= }}</ref> [[Genocide Watch]],<ref>{{cite web | title =Genocide and politicide watch: Iran | work = | publisher =Genocide Watch; The International Alliance to End Genocide | date =2012-03-28 | url =http://www.genocidewatch.org/iran.html | accessdate = 2012-03-28}}</ref> [[Sentinel Project for Genocide Prevention]],<ref>{{cite web| last = Seyfried | first = Rebeka | title =Progress report from Mercyhurst: Assessing the risk of genocide in Iran | work =Iranian Baha'is | publisher = The Sentinel Project for Genocide Prevention | date =2012-03-21 | url =http://thesentinelproject.org/progress-update-from-mercyhurst-assessing-risk-of-genocide-iran/ | accessdate = 2012-03-28}}</ref> and the journals ''War Crimes, Genocide, & Crimes against Humanity''<ref>{{cite journal| last = Affolter | first =Friedrich W. | title =The Specter of Ideological Genocide: The Bahá’ís of Iran | journal =War Crimes, Genocide, & Crimes against Humanity | volume =1 | issue =1 | pages =75–114 | publisher =Criminal Justice Program of Penn State Altoona | date = January 2005 | url =http://www.altoona.psu.edu/journals/war-crimes/articles/V1/v1n1a3.pdf | issn =1551-322X | accessdate = 2012-03-28}}</ref> and ''Journal of Genocide Research''.<ref>{{cite journal | last =Momen | first =Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen | title =The Babi and Baha’i community of Iran: a case of "suspended genocide"? | journal =Journal of Genocide Research | volume =7 | issue =2 | pages =221–241 | date = June 2005 | url =http://www.nhbahais.com/BahaiPapers/suspended_genocide.pdf | accessdate = 2012-03-28 | doi=10.1080/14623520500127431}}</ref>
A summary of 2013 incidents of prison sentences, fines and punishments showed that these were more than twice as likely to apply to Bahá'ís as any other religious minority in Iran and that the total rate of such cases had gone up by 36% over 2012.<ref>"79 religious minorities were sentenced to a total of 3620 months in prison, 200 months probation, 75 lashings and 41,030,000,000 rials in fines. In this area, 49% of the cases involved Baha’i minorities, 16% Christian and Dervish and 14% Sunni minority. Arrests of religious minorities increased by 36% in relation to last year." - {{cite news| title =Human rights activists in Iran publish disturbing annual report summarizing human rights violations in 2013 | newspaper =irandailybrief.com | date =23 January 2014 | url =http://www.irandailybrief.com/2014/01/23/human-rights-activists-in-iran-publish-disturbing-annual-report-summarizing-human-rights-violations-in-2013/| accessdate = January 24, 2014}}</ref>
==Size==
===Early reports=== The first known survey of the religion comes from an unpublished work in 1919–1920 gathered by [[John Esslemont]] and had been intended to be part of his well-known [[Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era]].{{sfn|Momen|2004|pp=63-106}} In it, consulting various individuals, he summarizes the religion's presence in Egypt, Germany, India, Iran, Iraq, Turkestan, and the United States. It did not arrive at a total but did have some regional statistics based on some individual reports. In Iran "The Cause has not only spread in important centres, but even in remote villages and corners…. In Teheran alone there are probably 10,000 Bahais.… [The] population of Teheran [is] 750,000.… Khorassan: villages where the whole population is Bahai. Esphahan, places where 2/3 of the people are Bahais. In Azerbayjan, villages where 1/2 are Bahais."

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Bahá'í sidebar}} The [[Bahá'í Faith]] is a minority religion in all Oceania countries.It forms majority in the [[Nanumea]] Island of [[Tuvalu]].<ref name="state.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2007/90157.htm|title=Tuvalu|publisher=}}</ref>
The [[Bahá'í Faith]] is a diverse and widespread religion founded by [[Bahá'u'lláh]] in the 19th century in Iran. Bahá'í sources usually estimate the worldwide Bahá'í population to be above 5 million.<ref>{{cite web |title=Worldwide Community |author=Bahá'í International Community | publisher = Bahá'í International Community |year = 2006 |accessdate =31 May 2006 |url= http://www.bahai.org/dir/worldwide| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060613035122/http://bahai.org/dir/worldwide| archive-date= 13 June 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Most encyclopedias and similar sources estimate between 5 and 6 million Bahá'ís in the world in the early 21st century.<ref name="britannica_stats">{{cite web |title=Worldwide Adherents of All Religions by Six Continental Areas, Mid-2002 |work=Enyclopædia Britannica | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica |year = 2002 |accessdate =31 May 2006 |url= http://www.britannica.com/eb/table?tocId=9394911}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Major Religions of the World Ranked by Number of Adherents |author= adherents.com | publisher = adherents.com |year = 2002 |accessdate =28 August 2005 |url= http://www.adherents.com/Religions_By_Adherents.html#Baha'i}}</ref> The religion is almost entirely contained in a single, organized, hierarchical community, but the Bahá'í population is spread out into almost every country and ethnicity in the world, being recognized as the second-most geographically widespread religion after Christianity.<ref name="britannica_stats"/> See [[Bahá'í statistics]].
==Australia== [[File:Bahaitemplesydney.JPG|thumb|150px|right|[[Sydney Bahá'í Temple]]]] {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Australia}} The Bahá'í Faith in [[Australia]] has a long history beginning with a mention by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the son of the founder of the religion, in 1916<ref name="tab1">{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-12.html.iso8859-1 | pages = 40/42 |origyear = 1916–17}}</ref> following which United Kingdom/American emigrants John and Clara Dunn came to Australia in 1920.<ref name="hist">{{cite web|title=Australian Bahá'í History |work=Official website of the Bahá'ís of Australia |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Australia |url=http://www.bahai.org.au/scripts/WebObjects.exe/BNO.woa/wa/pages?page=who_we_are/australian_bahai_history.html |accessdate=20 July 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719132045/http://www.bahai.org.au/scripts/WebObjects.exe/BNO.woa/wa/pages?page=who_we_are%2Faustralian_bahai_history.html |archive-date=19 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> They found people willing to convert to the [[Bahá'í Faith]] in several cities while further immigrant Bahá'ís also arrived.<ref name="miller">[http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/sbn/sbn33/sab3.htm William Miller (b. Glasgow 1875) and Annie Miller (b. Aberdeen 1877) – The First Believers in Western Australia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226054047/http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/sbn/sbn33/sab3.htm |date=26 February 2008 }} The Scottish Bahá'í No.33 – Autumn, 2003</ref> The first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in [[Melbourne]]<ref name="vict">{{Cite book |first = Graham |last = Hassall |contribution = Seventy Five Years of the Bahá'í Faith in Victoria |contribution-url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_75-years_bahai_victoria |title = presented at a dinner marking 75 years of the Bahá'í Faith in Victoria |date = December 1998 |publisher = Association for Bahá'í Studies, Australia |url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_75-years_bahai_victoria |id = }}</ref> followed by the first election of the [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in 1934.<ref name="Hands">[http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963], Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land, pages 22 and 46.</ref>
When [[persecution of Bahá'ís]] intensified in [[Iran]] in 1955, [[Shoghi Effendi]], then head of the religion, suspended plans for a [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in [[Tehran]], and in its place commissioned the [[Kampala]] Bahá'í House of Worship and the [[Sydney Bahá'í House of Worship]].<ref name="jrh-hassall">{{cite journal|last1=Hassall|first1=Graham|title=The Bahá'í Faith in Australia 1947-1963|journal=Journal of Religious History|date=December 2012|volume=36|issue=4|pages=563–576|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9809.2012.01231.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jorh.2012.36.issue-4/issuetoc|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> According to [[Jennifer Taylor (architect)|Jennifer Taylor]], a historian at [[Sydney University]], the latter was among Sydney's four most significant religious buildings constructed in the twentieth century.<ref name="dict-syd">{{cite web|last1=Dictionary of Sydney staff writer|title=Baha'i House of Worship|url=http://dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/bahai_house_of_worship|website=Dictionary of Sydney|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> It was the world's fourth [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] to be completed, dedicated in 1961.<ref name="iranica">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Rafati | first = V. | author-link = | author2-last = Sahba | author2-first = F. | author2-link = Fariborz Sahba | editor-last = Yarshater | editor-first = Ehsan | title = BAHAISM ix. Bahai Temples | encyclopedia = Encyclopaedia Iranica | volume = 3 | pages = 465–467 | publisher = | location = New York | date = 1996 | edition = Online | url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bahaism-ix | accessdate = 24 December 2016}}</ref> [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] when the House of Worship was designed, called it the "Mother Temple of the whole [[Pacific]] area" and the "Mother Temple of the [[Antipodes]]."<ref name="bahai-encyc">{{cite web|last1=Badiee|first1=Julie and the Editors|title=Mashriqu’l-Adhkár|url=http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70:mashriqul-adhkar&catid=36:administrationinstitutions#sydney|website=The Bahá'i Encyclopedia Project|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref>
Though they had been denied entry in 1948, Iranian Bahá'ís began to be admitted in 1973 where persecution again rose.<ref name="pers">{{Cite book |last = Hassall |first = Graham |last2 = (ed.) Ata |first2 = Abe |title = Religion and Ethnic Identity, An Australian Study |place = Melbourne |publisher = Victoria College & Spectrum |year = 1989 |pages = Chapter "Persian Bahá'ís in Australia" |url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_persian_bahais_australia |nopp = true }}</ref> Since the 1980s the Bahá'ís of Australia have become involved and spoken out on a number of civic issues – from ==Hawai'i== In 2000, Paul Sjoquist of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the Hawaiian Islands estimated that there were as many as 1,000 followers in Hawaii.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title= Baha’is to solemnize martyrdom of man who predicted prophet |url= https://bahai-library.com/newspapers/2000/062400.html |work= [[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |location= Honolulu, Hawaii |date= June 24, 2000 |access-date= June 24, 2017 }}</ref>
==Kiribati== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Kiribati}} The only substantial non-Christian population is of the [[Bahá'í Faith]]. The Bahá'í Faith in Kiribati begins after 1916 with a mention by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, that Bahá'ís should take the religion to the [[Gilbert Islands]] which form part of modern Kiribati.<ref name="tab1"/> The first Bahá'ís [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneered]] to the island of [[Abaiang]](aka Charlotte Island, of the Gilbert Islands), on 4 March 1954.<ref name="50th">{{Cite news| last = Bahá'í International Community | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = Sailing in for a jubilee| newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 4 March 2004 | url =http://news.bahai.org/story/301}}</ref> They encountered serious opposition from some Catholics on the islands and were eventually deported and the first convert banished to his home island.<ref name="hassal-pacific">{{Cite news |last = Hassall |first = Graham |author-link = |title = Bahá'í Faith in the Asia Pacific Issues and Prospects |periodical = Bahá'í Studies Review |volume=6 |pages = 1–10 |year = 1996 |url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_asia-pacific_issues }}</ref> However, in one year there was a community of more than 200 Bahá'ís<ref name="islandchurch">{{cite book| last = Finau | first = Makisi |author2=Teeruro Ieuti |author3=Jione Langi | editor-last = Forman| editor-first = Charles W.| title = Island Churches: Challenge and Change | publisher = Pacific Theological College and Institute for Pacific Studies | year = 1992 | pages = 101–2, 107 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=3EBW5XfcONUC&pg=PA101&lpg=PA101 | id =| isbn = 978-982-02-0077-7}}</ref> and a Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]].<ref name="hassal1">{{Cite book |first = Hassall |last = Graham |author2-link = |editor-last = Rubinstein |editor-first = Donald H. |contribution = Pacific Baha'i Communities 1950–1964 |contribution-url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_pacific |title = Pacific History: Papers from the 8th Pacific History Association Conference |year = 1992 |pages = 73–95 |publisher = University of Guam Press & Micronesian Area Research Center, Guam }}</ref> Three years later the island where the first convert was sent to was found to now have 10 Bahá'ís. By 1963 there were 14 assemblies.<ref name="stats">{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963| author = [[Hands of the Cause]] | pages = 26, 28}}</ref> As the [[Ellice Islands]] gained independence as Tuvalu and the Gilbert Islands and others formed Kiribati, the communities of Bahá'ís also reformed into separate institutions of National Spiritual Assemblies in 1981.<ref name="sum"/> The Bahá'ís had established a number schools by 1963<ref name="stats"/> and there are still such today – indeed the Ootan Marawa Bahá'í Vocational Institute being the only teacher training institution for pre-school teachers in Kiribati.<ref name="50th"/> The census figures are consistently between 2 and 3% for the Bahá'ís while the Bahá'ís claim numbers above 17%.<ref name="hassal-pacific"/> All together the Bahá'ís now claim more than 10,000 local people have joined the religion over the last 50 years and there are 38 local spiritual assemblies.<ref name="50th"/>
==Tuvala== Bahá'í Faith is practised by 3% of the population of Tuvala.<ref name="MDG">{{cite web| work= Ministry of Education and Sports, and Ministry of Finance and Economic Development from the Government of Tuvalu; and the United Nations System in the Pacific Islands |title= Tuvalu: Millennium Development Goal Acceleration Framework - Improving Quality of Education |date =April 2013|url= http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/library/MDG/MDG%20Acceleration%20Framework/MAF%20Reports/RBAP/MAF%20Tuvalu-FINAL-%20April%204.pdf| accessdate=13 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="usbd"/><ref name=report12>{{cite web| work= United States Department of State |title= International Religious Freedom Report 2012: Tuvalu |date =20 May 2013|url = https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2012/eap/208276.htm | accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> It forms majority in the [[Nanumea]] Island of [[Tuvalu]].<ref name="state.gov"/> Nanumea island is the only region in Oceania where Bahai's forms majority. ==Marshall Islands== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in the Marshall Islands}} The Bahá'í Faith in the Marshall Islands begins after 1916 with a mention by `Abdu'l-Bahá, then head of the religion, that Bahá'ís should take the religion there.<ref name="tab1"/> The first Bahá'í to [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] there arrived in August 1954<ref name="Atwater">{{Cite journal | first = Janet | last = Ruhe-Schoen | title = An Enchantment of the Heart – A Portrait of Marcia Steward, Knight of Bahá'u'lláh, First Bahá'í Pioneer to Chile and the Marshall Islands | work = The Chilean Temple Initiative | year = 2007 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United States | url =http://www.chilean-temple.org/images/stories/Early%20Baha/%27is/an_enchantment_of_the_heart.pdf | ref = harv }}</ref> however she could only stay until March 1955. Nevertheless, with successive pioneers and converts the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] in 1967 in [[Majuro]].<ref name="first">{{Cite journal | title = First Local Spiritual Assembly of…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 |issue = 442 | page =18 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm | ref = harv }}</ref> The community continued to grow and in 1977 elected its first [[National Spiritual Assembly]].<ref name="ABB">{{Cite journal| last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = H. Colllis Featherstone | journal = Australian Bahá'í Bulletin | volume = October | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Australia | year = 1990 | url = http://bahai-library.com/asia-pacific/featherstone.htm |accessdate =25 July 2010| ref = harv}}</ref> Before 1992 the Bahá'ís began to operate state schools under contract with the government.<ref name="hassal1"/> Middle estimates of the Bahá'í population are just over 1,000, or 1.50% in 2000.<ref name="adhere2000">{{cite encyclopedia | title = Top 20 Largest National Baha'i Populations | encyclopedia = Adherents.com| publisher = Adherents.com | url =http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html | year = 2008 | id = | accessdate =18 November 2008 | ref = harv| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081019165843/http://www.adherents.com/largecom/com_bahai.html| archivedate= 19 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==New Caledonia== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in New Caledonia}} The Bahá'í Faith in [[New Caledonia]] was first mentioned by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] in 1916,<ref name="tablets">{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-7.html.iso8859-1?#gr5 | page = 40 |origyear = 1916–17}}</ref> though the first [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] arrived in 1952<ref name="antipodes">{{cite book |last = Effendi |first = Shoghi |authorlink = Shoghi Effendi |title = Messages to the Antipodes:Communications from Shoghi Effendi to the Bahá'í Communities of Australasia |publisher = Mona Vale: Bahá'í Publications Australia |year = 1997 |url = http://bahai-library.com/shoghieffendi_messages_antipodes |isbn = 978-0-909991-98-2 }}</ref> during a temporary visit because of restrictive policies on English-speaking visitors.<ref name="hassal1" /> In 1961 Jeannette Outhey was the first [[New Caledonia]]n to join the religion and with other converts and [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] elected the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of [[Nouméa]].<ref name="outhey">{{Cite book |title = In Memoriam |journal = The Bahá'í World |volume = XVIII |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre |pages = 721–2 |year = 1986 |url = http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/720-748.html p.721-2 |isbn = 0-85398-234-1 |author = Universal House of Justice }}</ref> The Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of New Caledonia was elected in 1977.<ref name="hassal1"/> Multiplying its involvements through to today, the 2001 population was reported at 1,070 and growing.<ref name="stat">{{cite web |title = Territory of New Caledonia and Dependencies |work = Operation World – Pacific |publisher = Patrick J. St. G. Johnstone |year = 2001 |url = http://www.operationworld.org/country/newc/owtext.html |accessdate =26 July 2008 }}</ref>

Plan]] which mentions New Zealand<ref name="ToDP8">{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = The Bahá'ís of New Zealand elected their first independent [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in 1957.<ref name="timeline">{{cite web|title=New Zealand community – Historical timeline |work=New Zealand Community |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of New Zealand |url=http://www.bahai.org.nz/what_is_bahai/NZ_timeline.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023184025/http://www.bahai.org.nz/what_is_bahai/NZ_timeline.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 October 2007 |accessdate=19 September 2009 }}</ref> By 1963 there were four Assemblies, and 18 localities with smaller groups of Bahá'ís.<ref name="stats"/> The 2006 census reports about 2800 Bahá'ís<ref name="census">{{cite journal | last = Nachowitz | first = Todd | title = New Zealand as a Multireligious Society: Recent Census Figures and Some Relevant Implications | journal = Aotearoa Ethnic Network Journal | volume = 02 | issue = 2 | publisher = Ruth DeSouza | date = August 2007 | url = http://www.aen.org.nz/journal/2/2/AENJ.2.2.Nachowitz.pdf | issn = 1177-3472 | id = | accessdate =19 September 2009 | ref = harv}}</ref> in some 45 local assemblies and about 20 smaller groups of Bahá'ís<ref name="Kapiti">{{cite web|title=About Us |work=The Bahá'í Community of the Kapiti Coast District of New Zealand |publisher=Local Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Kapiti |url=http://www.kapitibahai.org.nz/collateral/Kapiti_Welcome.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016043211/http://www.kapitibahai.org.nz/collateral/Kapiti_Welcome.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 October 2008 |accessdate=30 September 2009 }}</ref> though the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] estimated there were some 7,000 Bahá'ís in 2005.<ref name="WCE-05"/>
==Papua New Guinea== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Papua New Guinea}}
The Bahá'í Faith in Papua New Guinea begins after 1916 with a mention by [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, that Bahá'ís should take the religion there.<ref name="tab1"/> The first Bahá'ís move there (what Bahá'ís mean by "[[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneering]]",) in Papua New Guinea arrived there in 1954.<ref name="BWN">{{cite news | title =A life in pursuit of noble endeavors | newspaper =Bahá'í World News Service | publisher =Bahá’í International Community | date =29 June 2004 | url =http://news.bahai.org/story/307 | accessdate = 11 December 2012 }}</ref> With local converts the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1958.<ref name="BWN50th">{{cite news | title =Celebrations held throughout the land |newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | date =8 May 2004 | url =http://news.bahai.org/story/312 | accessdate = 11 December 2012}}</ref> The first National Spiritual Assembly was then elected in 1969.<ref name="sum">{{cite web | last = Hassall | first = Graham |author2=Universal House of Justice |title = National Spiritual Assemblies statistics 1923-1999 | work = Assorted Resource Tools | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url =http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation | accessdate = 2 April 2008}}</ref> The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on''[[World Christian Encyclopedia]]'') estimated some 60000 or 0.9% of the nation were Bahá'ís in 2005<ref name="WCE-05">{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 11 December 2012}}</ref> though the 2012 [[CIA Factbook]] estimated 1/3rd of that citing national census figures from 2000.<ref name="CIARef">{{cite encyclopedia | title =East & Southeast Asia - Papua New Guinea |encyclopedia = CIA World Factbook | url =https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pp.html | date =13 November 2012 |accessdate = 11 December 2012 }}</ref> Either way it is the largest minority religion in Papua New Guinea, if a small one.
==Tonga== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Tonga}} The Bahá'í Faith in Tonga started after being set as a goal to introduce the religion in 1953,<ref name="plan">{{Cite book |first = Graham |last = Hassall |editor-last = H. Rubinstein |editor-first = Donald |contribution = Pacific Baha'i Communities 1950–1964 |contribution-url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_pacific |title = Pacific History: Papers from the 8th Pacific History Association Conference |year = 1992 |pages = 73–95 |publisher = University of Guam Press & Micronesian Area Research Center, Guam }}</ref> and Bahá'ís arrived in 1954.<ref name="gold">{{Cite news |last = Tuitahi |first = Sione |last2 = Bolouri |first2 = Sohrab |title = Tongan Baha'is parade to the palace |newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service |date = 28 January 2004 |url = http://www.bahaiworldnews.org/story/286 }}</ref> With conversions and [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1958.<ref name="hassal-pacific"/> From 1959 the [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] of Tonga and their local institutions were members of a Regional Spiritual Assembly of the South Pacific.<ref name="Tablets">{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html | pages = 31–32 |origyear = 1916–17}}</ref> By 1963 there were five local assemblies.<ref name="stats" /> Less than forty years later, in 1996, the Bahá'ís of Tonga established their paramount [[Bahá'í school]] in the form of the [[Ocean of Light International School]].<ref>{{Cite news |last = Bahá'í International Community |author-link = Bahá'í International Community |title = Ocean of Light School celebrates 10th anniversary |newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service |date = 17 July 2006 |url = http://news.bahai.org/story/461 }}</ref> Around 2004 there were 29 local spiritual assemblies<ref name="gold"/> and about 5% of the national population were members of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] though the [[Tonga Broadcasting Commission]] maintained a policy that does not allow discussions by members of the Baha'i Faith of its founder, [[Bahá'u'lláh]] on its radio broadcasts.<ref name="statedept">{{cite web | url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71356.htm | title = International Religious Freedom Report – Tonga | date = 15 September 2006 | accessdate =15 September 2008 | authors = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | publisher = United States State Department}}</ref>
==Samoa== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in American Samoa and Samoa}} The Bahá'í Faith in Samoa and [[American Samoa]] begins with the then head of the religion, [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], mentioning the islands in 1916,<ref name="tablets"/> inspiring Bahá'ís on their way to Australia to stop in Samoa in 1920.<ref name="dunns"> {{cite conference | last = Hassall | first = Graham | title = Clara and Hyde Dunn | booktitle = draft of "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | date = 9 March 1994 | url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_clara_hyde_dunn | accessdate =15 June 2008}}</ref> Thirty four years later another Bahá'í from Australia [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneered]] to Samoa in 1954.<ref name="nsa">{{cite web |author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Samoa |title=50th Anniversary of the Bahá'í Faith in Samoa |work=Waves of One Ocean, Official Bahá'í website |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Samoa |date=February 2004 |url=http://bci.org/bahaisamoa/information.html |accessdate=15 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904043508/http://bci.org/bahaisamoa/information.html |archivedate=4 September 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> With the first converts the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1961,<ref name="timeline-2">{{Cite news |last = International Community |first = Bahá'í |author-link = Bahá'í International Community |title = Timeline of significant evens in the history of the Bahá'í Faith in Samoa and American Samoa (1954 -2004.) |newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service |date = 30 November 2004 |url = http://news.bahai.org/multimedia/slideshow.php?storyid=337 }}</ref> and the Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] was first elected in 1970. Following the conversion of the then Head of State of Samoa, [[Malietoa Tanumafili II of Samoa|King Malietoa Tanumafili II]],<ref name="state">{{cite book |last = International Community |first = Bahá'í |author-link = Bahá'í International Community |title = Century of Light |publisher = Bahá'í International Community |date = September 2006 |location = Project Gutenberg |url = http://www.gutenberg.org/files/19267/19267-h/19267-h.html |page = 122 }}</ref> the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] of the Pacific Islands was finished in 1984 and the Bahá'í community reached a population of over 3,000 in about the year 2000.<ref name="encarta">{{cite encyclopedia |title=Samoa Facts and Figures from Encarta – People |encyclopedia=Encarta |volume=Online |publisher=Microsoft |year=2008 |url=http://encarta.msn.com/fact_631504895/samoa_facts_and_figures.html |accessdate=15 June 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kwPpSkzv?url=http://encarta.msn.com/fact_631504895/samoa_facts_and_figures.html |archivedate=31 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |ref=harv |df=dmy }}</ref>

{{Criticism of Judaism}} '''Criticism of Conservative Judaism''' is widespread in the [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish community]], although the movement also has its critics in [[Reform Judaism]] and in other streams of Judaism. While the [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative movement]] professes fidelity to Jewish tradition, it considers ''[[Halakha]]'' (Jewish [[religious law]]) to be a dynamic process that needs reinterpreting in modern times. The criticism by Orthodox Jews and traditionalists within the movement itself revolves around the following:
* Conservative Judaism, or some of its [[Conservative responsa|decisions]] and [[Conservative Halakha|positions]] does not follow halakha, according to many Orthodox Jews, because: ** The legal analyses of its [[Committee on Jewish Law and Standards|rabbinate]] [[Deconstruction|deconstruct]] or manipulate [[Mitzvah|religious obligations]], rather than being faithful to and fostering respect for them; ** It hoists certain historical or cultural assumptions onto a law, then disavows the assumption, granting itself license to disavow the law itself; {{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} ** It issues "emergency decrees" in the absence of legitimate emergencies, rather than following a legitimate, faithful, or reverential approach to halakha; ** Its decisions consistently lead to more lax, rather than stringent or balanced observance; ** It generally makes communal decrees through a council of (often lay) leaders, rather than relying exclusively on Talmudic scholars, resulting in decisions reflecting popular opinion rather than scholarship; and ** Accommodating the values and likeness of the broader society has taken precedence over a dedication to the internal integrity of halakhic sources.
Critics also claim that the legal analysis of the Conservative movement tends to be ideologically-driven, resulting in intended outcomes to such an extent that it is outside the bounds of traditional halakhic analysis.
==Criticism from Orthodoxy== From [[Haredi Judaism]] perspective, criticism is exemplified by Rabbi [[Avi Shafran]] of [[Agudath Israel of America]]. Shafran wrote in 2001 that the Conservative movement's leaders "trample" halakha while proclaiming fealty to it. He argued that the movement was a failure because nearly three-quarters of Conservative Jews said that they [[Who is a Jew?|consider a Jew]] to be anyone raised Jewish, even if his or her mother was a gentile—the official Reform position, rejected by Conservative leaders as nonhalachic.<ref>Safran cited a study of Conservative congregants conducted by the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America|Jewish Theological Seminary’s]] Jack Wertheimer in 1996. Shafran also noted that only about half of Conservative [[B'nai Mitzvah|bar and bat mitzvah]] receptions were [[kosher]], by any standard.</ref> Shafran further argued that Conservative Judaism "movement is not honest" because, though stating its commitment to halakhah (Jewish law), it approved the [[Ordination of women#Judaism|ordination of women]] based on a commission containing mostly laypeople and only one Talmud scholar. Shafran stated that the movement should have relied on the [[Talmud]] faculty of JTS.<ref>Shafran also stated that the decision was made against faculty wishes. He cited Rabbi [[Daniel Gordis]], former dean of the [[University of Judaism|University of Judaism’s]] [[Ziegler School of Rabbinic Studies]] for stating that “the Conservative Movement allows its laity to set its religious agenda.”{{Cite web |url=http://www.jewishamerica.com/ja/features/ConLie.cfm |title=The Conservative Lie |accessdate=13 January 2009 |date=February 2001 |publisher=Moment Magazine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129182155/http://jewishamerica.com/ja/features/ConLie.cfm |archivedate=29 January 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>[[Avi Shafran]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20060106063953/http://www.momentmag.com/archive/feb01/feat2.html "The Conservative Lie"], ''[[Moment (magazine)|Moment]]'', February 2001.</ref> Similarly, in 2006, Rabbi Shafran criticized the decision by the Conservative movement's [[Committee on Jewish Law and Standards]] to adopt a [[responsum]] liberalizing its position on homosexual conduct. Shafran repeated his assertion that the Conservative movement, despite its "claim of halachic integrity", did not follow the "true halachic process".<ref>Avi Shafran, [http://jta-vip.mediapolis.com/cgi-bin/iowa/news/article/20070101Conservativedecisio.html "Conservative vote chance for halachic Jews to go Orthodox"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321131742/http://jta-vip.mediapolis.com/cgi-bin/iowa/news/article/20070101Conservativedecisio.html |date=2007-03-21 }}, [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]], December 7, 2006.</ref>
Moreover, Rabbi [[Avi Weiss]], an [[Open Orthodoxy|Open Orthodox]] rabbi on the left wing of Orthodox Judaism, also characterized the differences between Orthodox and Conservative Judaism in a manner critical of the Conservative approach:
:Despite variations in style and approach, the system that we hold as holy sets us fundamentally apart from our Conservative co-religionists whose vision of the Jewish legal process is so very different in each of these three fundamental areas of Halakha: ''[[Torah|Torah mi-Sinai]]'' ["Torah from Sinai", the belief that the Torah was given by God to Moses on Mount Sinai], rabbinic interpretation, and rabbinic legislation.
:The belief in ''Torah mi-Sinai'' is, for all Orthodox Jews, the foundation of faith and at the core of the halakhic process. Conservative Judaism does not subscribe to this teaching. Moreover, in the area of rabbinic law, we Orthodox—Modern and Right alike—contend that legal authority is cumulative, and that a contemporary ''[[posek]]'' (legal decisor) can only issue judgments based on a full history of Jewish [[legal precedent]]. In contrast, the implicit argument of the Conservative movement is that precedent provides illustrations of possible positions rather than binding law. Conservatism, therefore, remains free to select whichever position within the prior legal history appeals to it. Likewise, we adhere and turn to the wisdom of the most distinguished religio-legal authorities in making Halakhic determinations. Not so the Conservatives. Truth be told, when the Conservative movement faced some of its most controversial "new ''halakhot''", such as the ordination of women, it turned away from its own Talmudic scholars and experts in Halakha, who had almost universally rejected the reasoning on which this new practice was to be based, and who have since virtually all left the faculty of the Jewish Theological Seminary.
:Finally, in understanding the value of rabbinic law legislated by today's rabbis, it must be appreciated that at this juncture in our people's history in [[United States|America]], the Orthodox community is blessed with large numbers of ritually observant Jews. Across the spectrum of Orthodoxy, myriads of people meticulously keep [[Shabbat]] (the Sabbath), [[Kashrut]] (the Dietary Laws), ''[[Niddah|Taharat ha-mishapahah]]'' (the Laws of Family Purity) and pray three times a day. Thus, if a "permissive custom" is accepted, it can become binding. This is not true of Conservatism's constituency, which is generally not composed of ritually-observant Jews. Thus, only in our community if a "permissive custom" is accepted, can it be meaningful.<ref>[[Avraham Weiss]], {{cite web |url= http://www.yctorah.org/component/option,com_docman/task,doc_download/gid,143 |title= "Open Orthodoxy! A Modern Orthodox Rabbi's Creed" |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070928083202/http://www.yctorah.org/component/option%2Ccom_docman/task%2Cdoc_download/gid%2C143 |archivedate= 2007-09-28 |df= }} {{small|(766 [[Kibibyte|KiB]])}}, ''Judaism'', Fall 1997.</ref>
==Criticism from Conservative traditionalists== At the 2006 convention of the [[Rabbinical Assembly]], the Conservative movement's official rabbinical organization, Rabbi [[Ismar Schorsch]] said that the Conservative movement had "lost faith in itself" and "become Reform."<ref name="Forward">Jennifer Siegel, [http://www.forward.com/articles/6796/ "Conservative Rabbi, in Swan Song, Warns Against Liberal Shift"], ''[[The Jewish Daily Forward]]'', March 24, 2006.</ref>
In an interview, Rabbi Schorsch, who was about to retire as [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the Jewish Theological Seminary, criticized rabbis and activists who were lobbying to change the Conservative movement's opposition to [[same-sex union]]s and the [[Semicha|ordination]] of gay clergy. He described their methods as using scholarship to overturn halakha rather than to foster appreciation of it.
:If the Conservative movement chooses to do something at the expense of the halachic system, then it's going to pay the price down the road... The erosion of our fidelity to Halacha is what brings us close to Reform Judaism.<ref name="Forward"/>
Rabbi Schorsch made similar criticism two months later in his final [[commencement address]] at Jewish Theological Seminary, in which he spoke of the "malaise of Conservative Judaism", its "impoverishment", and its "grievous failure of nerve". He also criticized the Seminary, one of the chief academic and intellectual institutions of Conservative Judaism:
:In the wake of [[Mordecai Kaplan]]'s wholesale reduction of halakhah to [[Folkways (sociology)|folkways]], the function of history shifted to vindicating change. Ever more identified by the inane mantra of "tradition and change," Conservative Judaism lost access to critical scholarship as a source for religious meaning, with nothing substantially spiritual to replace it. ...
:Our impoverishment is sadly exemplified by the ambivalence toward critical scholarship in ''Etz Hayim'', the movement's new ''[[humash]]''. As commentary, the abridgement of the [[Jewish Publication Society]] Torah Commentary is so eviscerated as to betray not the slightest trace of the plenitude of the original to generate spiritual meaning through empathetic scholarship. As exposition, the end notes, with a few striking exceptions, are spiritually inert. Their rabbinic authors go through the paces without passion, making no effort to extract religious significance from the scholarship being mediated. While Conservative rabbis often chide the research oriented faculty of JTS for allegedly doing just that in their classes, as transmitters of scholarship, the rabbis replicated what they condemn. Ironically, the rare spiritual voice to be heard in the end notes usually emanates from one or another of the academics in the roster. ...
:With history no more than an argument for supersession, the halakhic yoke has lost its lightness. Great scholarship has ceased to energize it as it had in the past. Once, the polarity of truth and faith at the Seminary had made it home for the acme of twentieth-century Jewish scholarship, a venue of ferment and fertility. Faith once moved us to study our heritage deeply, while truth asked of us that we do it critically, in light of all that we know. Willful ignorance was never an acceptable recourse. The interaction set us apart as the vital center of modern Judaism.
:With frequency, fundamental changes come more easily. Our forebearers embraced history to enlarge and enrich Jewish observance; we wield it, if at all, to shrink it. How quickly have we forgotten the bracing spiritual power of [[Gershom Scholem|Gershon Scholem's]] ''Major Trends in Jewish Mysticism'', [[Yehezkel Kaufmann|Yehezkel Kaufmann's]] ''Religion of Israel'', [[Saul Lieberman|Saul Lieberman's]] ''Hellenism in Jewish Palestine'', [[Nahum M. Sarna|Nahum Sarna's]] ''Understanding Genesis'', or [[Jacob Milgrom|Jacob Milgrom's]] commentaries to [[Leviticus]] and [[Book of Numbers|Numbers]]. Our addiction to instant gratification has stripped us of the patience to appreciate any discourse whose rhetoric is dense and demanding. Mindlessly, we grasp for the quick spiritual fix.
:A grievous failure of nerve affects Conservative Judaism. We have lost confidence in the viability of the distinctive polarity that once resonated within. It is not a slick new motto that we need, but a vigorous reaffirmation of the old which gloriously captures our essence. When [[Solomon Schechter|Schechter]] left England in 1902 to head the Seminary, he inveighed against [[History of the Jews in England|Anglo–Jewry]] for its shallow quest for a decorous spiritual Judaism. What the confounding epoch of [[Jewish Emancipation|emancipation]] actually called for, he claimed, was more spiritual Jews. To educate and inspire Jews of such sturdy timbre remains the unaltered mission of a vastly expanded Seminary in an age of pampered and promiscuous individualists contemptuous of all norms. A Seminary true to itself still holds out the brightest beacon for the future of Conservative Judaism.<ref>Ismar Schorsch, [http://www.jtsa.edu/about/communications/speeches/sca.shtml Commencement Address] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070419092452/http://www.jtsa.edu/about/communications/speeches/sca.shtml |date=2007-04-19 }}, 112th Commencement Exercises of The Jewish Theological Seminary, May 18, 2006.</ref>
Rabbi [[David Golinkin]], the chair of the Masorti movement's ''[[Va'ad Halakha]]'' (Israel's counterpart to the Committee on Jewish Law and Standards), criticized the Conservative movement's proposal to liberalize its position on homosexual conduct. He wrote that such a change would "split the Conservative movement in two ... drive away the most halakhically observant laypeople in our synagogues, and ... have a devastating effect on the Conservative movement throughout the world.” According to Rabbi Golinkin, if the Conservative movement adopted such a change, most Israelis would see little difference between the Masorti movement (Israeli Conservative Judaism in Israel) and Reform Judaism.<ref name="Prouser">[[Joseph Prouser|Joseph H. Prouser]], [http://www.uscj.org/The_Conservative_Mov7074.html "The Conservative Movement and Homosexuality: Settled Law in Unsettling Times"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070429173219/http://www.uscj.org/The_Conservative_Mov7074.html |date=2007-04-29 }}, ''United Synagogue Review'', Fall 2006.</ref>
Rabbi [[Joseph Prousser]], a member of the Committee on Jewish Law and Standards, also lobbied against the proposal, arguing that its adoption would result in "a fractured Conservative movement" that is "rendered less viable". He wrote that adopting such a change would represent a "failure of moral and religious leadership" and that such a significant change would diminish the Conservative rabbinate's ability to provide meaningful religious guidance to its congregants:
:Such sweeping change in Jewish law will make the Law Committee and the Conservative rabbinate poor role models for our religious charges. If we essentially declare so fundamental a halachic obligation inoperative, based on a minority’s subjective reading of contemporary reality, how can we deny individual Jews unbridled autonomy in determining which demands of Jewish law remain binding and personally meaningful? Jewish law would be rendered unrecognizable—as law—to our laity, and to all but the most erudite and progressive legal theorists. ...
:Lending credence to the notion that a person’s core identity is defined by physical drives and sexual desire represents a failure of moral and religious leadership. Rabbinic discourse that even unintentionally vests [[moral authority]] in the inclination of the individual, rather than in the will of a commanding God, seems a far graver transgression than prohibited, albeit loving, expressions of intimacy between homosexuals.<ref name="Prouser"/>
After the Committee on Jewish Law and Standards adopted the responsum liberalizing its position on homosexual conduct, Rabbi Prouser and three other members of the Committee—Rabbis [[Joel Roth]], [[Mayer Rabinowitz]], and [[Leonard Levy (rabbi)|Leonard Levy]]—resigned in protest.
==Criticism from Reform Jews== Rabbi Paul Menitoff, Executive Vice President of the Reform movement’s [[Central Conference of American Rabbis]], wrote in a 2004 essay that Conservative Judaism would either merge with Reform Judaism or "disappear".<ref name="Cohen">Debra Nussbaum Cohen, [http://www.thejewishweek.com/news/newscontent.php3?artid=9154 "Reform Leader Predicts Demise Of Conservatives"], ''[[The Jewish Week]]'', March 5, 2004.</ref> Rabbi Menitoff said that the Conservative movement's policies were at odds with the principles of its young adult members on issues such as [[Interreligious marriage#Judaism|intermarriage]], [[Patrilineality|patrilineal descent]], and the ordination of lesbians and gay men—all issues that Conservative Judaism then-opposed yet Reform Judaism supported.<ref name="Cohen"/><ref name="Berkofsky">Joe Berkofsky, [http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/21714/edition_id/441/format/html/displaystory.html "Death of Conservative Judaism? Reform leader’s swipe sparks angry rebuttals"], ''[[j.]]'', March 5, 2004.</ref> (The Conservative movement has since liberalized its policy concerning the ordination of gay clergy.<ref>[[Laurie Goodstein]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/07/us/07jews.html?ex=1323147600&en=d9af0c2c2de39221&ei=5088&partner ''Conservative Jews Allow Gay Rabbis and Unions''], [[The New York Times]], 2006.</ref>) To support his prediction, Rabbi Menitoff described Conservative Judaism's dilemma:
:If the Conservative movement capitulates regarding these core differences between Reform and Conservative Judaism, it will be essentially obliterating the need for its existence. If, alternatively, it stands firm, its congregants will vote with their feet.<ref name="Berkofsky"/>
Rabbi Menitoff's essay drew criticism from Conservative rabbis, two of whom described his prediction as "off base"<ref name="Cohen"/> and "wishful thinking."<ref name="Berkofsky"/> Rabbi Ismar Schorsch, then Chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary, pointed out that “at the beginning of the 20th century, all the Jewish pundits predicted the demise of Orthodoxy, and they all proved dead wrong. So Rabbi Menitoff has good company in bad predictions.”<ref name="Cohen"/>
==Criticism from third-wave feminists== Some [[third-wave feminist]]s have criticized Conservative Judaism's [[Role of women in Judaism#Conservative Judaism|efforts at integrating women]] as half-hearted attempts at [[egalitarianism]]. Instead of maintaining a traditional approach to worship and treating women as if they were men, what Dr. [[Rachel Adler]] calls "honorary men", some have suggested that the Conservative movement cannot become truly egalitarian until it reinterprets Judaism to reflect the perspectives and experiences of women.
In her 1998 book ''Engendering Judaism: An Inclusive Theology and Ethics'', Dr. Adler wrote:
:For many Conservative congregations, counting women in the [[minyan]] and [[Torah reading|calling them up to the Torah]] are recent innovations. But ... egalitarian Judaisms may tolerate women as participants by ignoring their distinctive experiences and concerns as women.<ref>[[Rachel Adler]], ''Engendering Judaism: An Inclusive Theology and Ethics'', [[Jewish Publication Society]], 1998. p. 62.</ref>

[[File:Dhanurasana.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Dhanurasana]] '''Dhanurasana''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|d|ɑː|n|ʊəˈr|ɑː|s|ɑː|n|ɑː}} {{respell|DAH|noo|RAH|sah|nah}}<ref>{{cite book |last1=Budilovsky |first1=Joan |last2=Adamson |first2=Eve |title=The complete idiot's guide to yoga |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b5pE8-Oyly0C |accessdate=11 April 2011 |edition=2 |year=2000 |publisher=Penguin |isbn=978-0-02-863970-3 |page=160}}</ref>; [[Sanskrit]]: धनुरासन; [[IAST]]: ''Dhanurāsana''), '''Bow Pose''',<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.yogajournal.com/poses/875 | title = Yoga Journal - Bow Pose | accessdate = 2011-04-09}}</ref> or sometimes '''Urdva Chakrasana''' (Upward Wheel Pose) is an [[asana]].
== Etymology ==
The name comes from the Sanskrit words धनुर (Dhanura) meaning "bow",<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.ashtangayoga.info/practice/asana-vinyasa-series/intermediate-series-nadi-shodhana/item/dhanurasana/ | title=Dhanurasana - AshtangaYoga.info | accessdate=11 April 2011}}</ref> and आसन (Asana) meaning "posture" or "seat".<ref name="Sinha1996">{{cite book |last=Sinha |first=S. C. |title=Dictionary of Philosophy |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-zzRvh1fRzEC&pg=PA18 |date=1 June 1996 |publisher=Anmol Publications |isbn=978-81-7041-293-9 |page=18}}</ref>
==Description== First the practitioner should lie prone and grasp the feet to lift the leg and chest to form a bow. Remain in this position for some time and then return to the previous position.

{{Distinguish|Diazinon}} '''Dianazene''' was the name given by [[L. Ron Hubbard]] to a vitamin supplement containing [[iron]], [[vitamin C]], and various [[B vitamins]], including especially large doses of [[niacin]]. Hubbard promoted it as a form of protection against radiation poisoning during the 1950s, saying that "Dianazene runs out radiation — or what appears to be radiation. It also proofs a person against radiation in some degree. It also turns on and runs out incipient cancer." <ref name="all-about-radiation">{{cite book | last = Hubbard | first = L. Ron | isbn = 978-0-88404-062-0 | title = [[All About Radiation]] }}</ref>
In 1958, the [[Food and Drug Administration]] seized and destroyed 21,000 Dianazene tablets from the Distribution Center Inc, a company with ties to the Church of Scientology, because they were falsely labeled as a preventative and treatment for radiation sickness.<ref name="Blue Sky">{{cite book | last = Atack | first = Jon | authorlink = Jon Atack | year = 1990 | title = A Piece of Blue Sky | publisher = Carol Publishing Group | location = New York, NY | isbn = 0-8184-0499-X}}</ref><ref>Wallis, Roy. ''Sectarianism: Analyses of Religious and Non-Religious Sects'', Page 92, 1975, {{ISBN|0-470-91910-8}}</ref><ref name="barefaced">{{cite book|author=Miller, Russell| authorlink=Russell Miller|title=Bare-faced Messiah, The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|publisher=Henry Holt & Co|location=New York|edition=First American|year=1987|isbn=0-8050-0654-0|pages=227–228}}</ref>
Vitamins continue to play a large role in the Scientology [[Purification Rundown]] and the secular version in the [[Narconon]] program, where it is similarly claimed that large quantities of niacin and other vitamins, combined with the heat in a sauna, can "purify" the body by allowing it to release [[toxin]]s stored in cellular [[Tissue (biology)|tissue]] and to "run out" or ameliorate prior radiation exposure including [[sunburn]].<ref>[[Clear Body, Clear Mind]] L. Ron Hubbard 1990</ref>
==Ingredients== A standard dose of Dianazene, according to Hubbard's 1957 book ''[[All About Radiation]]'', contained the following ingredients: *[[Vitamin B3|Vitamin B<sub>3</sub>]] ([[Niacin]]): 200 mg *[[Iron]] ([[Ferrous gluconate]]): 10 grains (600 mg) *Vitamin B<sub>1</sub> ([[Thiamine]]): 25 mg *Vitamin B<sub>2</sub> ([[Riboflavin]]): 50 mg *[[Vitamin C]] (Ascorbic acid): 200–500 mg *[[Calcium]] ([[Dicalcium phosphate]]): 15-20 grains (1000–1300 mg) <ref name="all-about-radiation" />
